review.title: Preorder-Based Triangle: A Modified Version of Bilattice-Based Triangle for Belief Revision in Nonmonotonic Reasoning
review.abstract: Bilattice-based triangle provides elegant algebraic structure for reasoning with vague and uncertain information. But the truth and knowledge ordering of intervals in bilattice-based triangle can not deal with nonmonotonic reasoning and are not always intuitive. In this work, we construct an alternative algebraic structure, namely poset-based triangle and we provide with proper logical connectives for this. It as an enhancement of the bilattice-based triangle to handle nonmonotonicity in logical reasoning.

metadata.title: Preorder-Based Triangle: A Modified Version of Bilattice-Based Triangle for Belief Revision in Nonmonotonic Reasoning

sections.heading: 1 Introduction:
sections.text: This year it is so far that it will only be a matter of time before an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: 2 Intervals as degree of belief:
sections.text: This section addresses some of the basic definitions and terms that will facilitate discussion in the coming sections. Uncertainty and incompleteness of information are inevitable in real-life reasoning, so sometimes it becomes difficult and misleading, if not impossible, to assign a precise degree of belonging to a fuzzy attribute or to assign a precise level of truth to a proposal. Therefore, assigning an interval of possible truth values is the natural solution. Intervals are suitable for describing the degree of expert belief that may not be precise (Nguyen, Kreinovich, & Zuo, 1997). If an expert chooses a value, say 0.8, as his degree of faith for a proposal, we can in fact only vaguely state that his chosen value is about 0.8 and can be represented by an interval, say [0.75, 0.85]. Otherwise, an interval can be considered a collection of possible truth values that an individual or several rational experts would assign to a proposal.

sections.heading: 2.1 Bilattice-based Triangle:
sections.text: Bilattices are ordered propositions in which elements are partially ordered in relation to two orders, one representing the degree of indeterminacy or truth (namely the order of truth) and the other the degree of certainty (namely the order of knowledge) (Arieli et al., 2004; Cornelis et al., 2007). A bilatticbased triangle or simply a triangle can be defined as: Definition 2.2. Let us leave L = (L, ≤ L) as a structure B (L) = (I), ≤ t, ≤ k), with each [x1, x2] | (x1, x2), [y1, y2] ≤ L x2}. A (bilatticbased) triangle is called a structure B (L) = (I (L), ≤ t, ≤ k), with each [x1, x2], [yb] interval (x2], [x2, yb] ≤ L (L) and vice versa (L).

sections.heading: 3 Inadequacy of Bilattice-based Triangle:
sections.text: All values within an interval are considered to be equally probable as the actual truth value of the underlying proposition. Therefore, the consideration of intervals as truth status or epistemic state of the propositions allows an efficient representation of the uncertainty and uncertainty of information and argumentation. However, the triangular structure suffers from the following defects that need to be eliminated.

sections.heading: 3.1 Inadequacy in modeling belief revision in nonmonotonic reasoning:
sections.text: In many cases, conclusions are drawn in the absence of complete information, and we must draw plausible conclusions based on the assumption that the world in which the thinking is carried out is normal and as expected. This is the best thing that can be done in contexts where the knowledge acquired is incomplete, but these conclusions may have to be abandoned in the light of further information. A sentence that has been assumed to be true may turn out to be false when new information is collected. Such repetitive faith changes are an essential component of non-monotonous thinking. This type of faith correction may not be adequately represented by Triangle. The following discussion will shed light on this problem.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Inadequacy of bilattice-based triangle in performing logical reasoning in application areas:
sections.text: Bilattice-based structures are put to use for logical reasoning with human detection and identity maintenance in visual surveillance systems by Shet et al. (Shet, 2007; Shet, Neumann, Ramesh, & Davis, 2007; Shet, Harwood, & Davis, 2006a).Multi-rated default bilattice (also known as prioritized default bilattice (Figure 3.b) has been used for identity and contextual reasoning in visual surveillance system (Shet et al., 2006a).In practice, however, logical facts are generated from image analysis that are based on machine learning and pattern recognition techniques and have generally noisy values. Thus, in practical applications it would be more realistic to attach beliefs to logical rules than values such as dt, df, etc., which are allowed in multivalued default bilattices.

sections.heading: 3.2 Truth ordering is not always accurate:
sections.text: In the bilatzian triangle for two intervals [x1, x2] and [y1, y2], [x1, x2] ≤ t [y1, y2] iff x1 ≤ y1 and x2 ≤ y2. According to this order, two intervals x and y are incomparable if x is a real sub-interval of y or vice versa, i.e. if one interval is completely within the other without a common boundary. The justification behind this incomparability is that if an interval, say y, is a real sub-interval of x, then the actual truth value caused by interval x (x) may be approximately greater or less than the value of y.

sections.heading: 4 Modification in Triangle structure:
sections.text: Based on the discussions in the two subsections above, the bilateral triangle will be modified.

sections.heading: 4.1 Modification in knowledge ordering:
sections.text: The order of knowledge can only be defined by the length of the intervals and independently of the real truth values they attempt to approximate. Thus, for two intervals [x1, x2] and [y1, y2], LI is the set of partial intervals of [0, 1] as shown in Figure 1. Equality of the width of the intervals is a necessary condition for x = y, but not a sufficient condition; because two different intervals may have the same width, e.g. [0,1, 0,2] and [0,7, 0,8]. This modified knowledge sorting (kp) overcomes the deficiencies shown in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.2.

sections.heading: 5 An alternative algebraic structure
sections.text: Based on these modifications, we propose a modified and more intuitive algebraic structure for the arrangement of intervals relative to the degree of truth and knowledge (or certainty). Notation: For an interval x-LI; xm and xw 0.5% are used to indicate the center (or center) and length of the interval; i.e. xm = (x1 + x2) / 2 and xw = (x2 − x1). The pair (xm, xw) specifies an interval x once and can therefore be used instead of the traditional representation [x1, x2]. Definition 5.1 is a preorder-based triangle a structure P (L) = (LI, ≤ tp), ≤ kp), defined for each [x1, x2] and [x2].

sections.heading: 6 Logical Operators on P(L)
sections.text: All logical operators, e.g. conjunction, disjunction, implication and negation, defined for bilattic-based triangles (B (L)) (Cornelis et al., 2007; Deschrijver et al., 2007), also apply to rule-based triangles (P (L)), but the modified order of truth and knowledge will include some changes in the definition and properties of connectives. Notations 0LI and 1LI represent intervals [0, 0] and [1, 1], respectively.

sections.text: Definition 6.15. An Implicator on (LI, ≤ tp) is a hybrid implicator class (Suym I · LI → LI mapping I (i.e. a figure with decreasing first and increasing second partial figure), which implicitly I (0LI, 0LI) = I (0LI, 1LI) = I (1LI, 1LI) = 0LI. sections.heading: 7 Conclusion:
sections.text: We conclude with a critical assessment of the proposed structure with respect to the bilatzik-based triangle. The structure, the precept-based triangle, together with the logical operators defined on it, provides a framework for thinking with imprecise, uncertain and incomplete information. In contrast to the bilatzik-based triangle, the precept-based triangle is capable of coping with repetitive changes in belief in nonmonotonous thinking. Furthermore, the order of truth in the new structure is more intuitive. The fact that the knowledge and truth order has now become completely orthogonal has a strong appeal in areas of application where nonmonotonous logical thinking with vague and incomplete information comes into play. As demonstrated here, all operators defined for bilatzik-based triangles are also suitable for the proposed structure and the modified truth order, giving rise to some new logical connections with interesting properties. Thus, the proposed analysis can be considered as a precursor improvement of the proposed triangle structure.

referenceMentions.context: This structure can be thought of as a unification of bilattice-based triangle and default bilattice (Ginsberg, 1988).
The natural ordering of degree of memberships (≤) can be extended to the set of intervals and that gives rise to IVFS (Sambuc, 1975).
An IVFS can be viewed as an L-fuzzy set (Goguen, 1967) and the corresponding lattice can be defined as (Deschrijver, Arieli, Cornelis, & Kerre, 2007):

Bilattices are ordered sets where elements are partially ordered with respect to two orderings, typically one depicts the degree of vagueness or truth (namely, truth ordering) and the other one depicting the degree of certainty (namely, knowledge ordering) (Arieli et al., 2004; Cornelis et al., 2007).

Bilattices are ordered sets where elements are partially ordered with respect to two orderings, typically one depicts the degree of vagueness or truth (namely, truth ordering) and the other one depicting the degree of certainty (namely, knowledge ordering) (Arieli et al., 2004; Cornelis et al., 2007).
In knowledge ordering, the intervals are ordered by set inclusion, as was suggested by Sandewall (Sandewall, 1989).
One important aspect of human commonsense reasoning is that it is nonmonotonic in nature (Brewka, 1991).
This type of scenario can be efficiently taken care of in the default bilattice (Ginsberg, 1988).
(Shet, 2007; Shet, Neumann, Ramesh, & Davis, 2007; Shet, Harwood, & Davis, 2006a).
Bilattice-based square (Arieli et al., 2005) has been used for human detection in visual surveillance system.

But it is pointed out by Dubois (Dubois, 2008) that square-like bilattices, where explicit representations of unknown (〈0, 0〉) and inconsistent (〈1, 1〉) epistemic states are allowed, can not preserve classical tautologies and sometimes give rise to unintuitive results.
The inference mechanism is specified in (Ginsberg, 1988).
The justification in support of this weak truth ordering is (Deschrijver, 2009)

conjunction, disjunction, implication and negation, defined for bilattice-based triangle (B(L)) (Cornelis et al., 2007; Deschrijver et al., 2007) are applicable for preorder-based triangle (P(L)) as well.

conjunction, disjunction, implication and negation, defined for bilattice-based triangle (B(L)) (Cornelis et al., 2007; Deschrijver et al., 2007) are applicable for preorder-based triangle (P(L)) as well.
This is the difference between negators on bilattice-based triangle (Cornelis et al., 2007) and preorder-based triangles.
Two important class of t-(co)norms defined for IVFS, namely t-representable and pseudo t-representable t-(co)norms (Deschrijver, 2008), can be defined over the preorder-based triangle structure.

metadata.abstractText: Bilattice-based triangle provides an elegant algebraic structure for reasoning with vague and uncertain information. But the truth and knowledge ordering of intervals in bilattice-based triangle can not handle repetitive belief revisions which is an essential characteristic of nonmonotonic reasoning. Moreover the ordering induced over the intervals by the bilattice-based triangle is not sometimes intuitive. In this work, we construct an alternative algebraic structure, namely preorder-based triangle and we formulate proper logical connectives for this. It is an enhancement of the bilattice-based triangle to handle belief revision in nonmonotonic reasoning.
